author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Hello, I am an automated registration bot. I help manage the registration process by checking your registration against a set of [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). If all these guidelines are met, this pull request will be merged automatically, completing your registration. It is **strongly recommended** to follow the guidelines, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

## 1. New package registration

Please make sure that you have read the [package naming guidelines](https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1).

## 2. [AutoMerge Guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/) are all met! âœ…

Your new package registration met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

## 3. To pause or stop registration

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.

_Tip: You can edit blocking comments to add `[noblock]` in order to unblock auto-merging._

<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

[noblock] I donâ€™t have a strong opinion on this, but wouldnâ€™t `TDLibJSON` be both slightly more readable and more appropriate, given the names of the upstream packages?

> Links
>
> * [TDLib](https://github.com/tdlib/td) â€“ Official library repository.
> * [TDLib_jll.jl](https://github.com/JuliaBinaryWrappers/TDLib_jll.jl) â€“ Julia wrapper for TDLib.

[noblock]

I donâ€™t mind renaming it, I was just going off this line:

> The code bindings within this package are autogenerated from the following Products: LibraryProduct: libtdjson.
https://github.com/JuliaBinaryWrappers/TDLib_jll.jl?tab=readme-ov-file#products

But yeah, changing the name is no big deal for us, what do you think?

[noblock]

You have mixed levels in the design, Iâ€™d prefer to move the client into a second-level module.
I donâ€™t see a problem with that. Thanks for the suggestion!

> Also see https://juliahub.com/ui/Packages/General/TelegramClient. Anything missing there?

[noblock] I have no idea; I'm really not in the wrapper-package market myself (never used BinaryBuilder). So I'm not sure about all the prevailing conventions. Bottom line is that it's pretty much up to you ðŸ˜‰ (or, you could ask on Slack/Discourse).

The potential overlap with `TelegramClient` is probably a more substantial point. Especially with the generally encouraged "descriptive" package naming scheme resulting in what should be "authoritative" packages, I would always push for contributing to an existing package over registering an alternative solution, from a community perspective. But I'm also not personally invested, so that's probably something you should work out with @aplavin

[noblock]

@aplavin, could you please unblock the auto-merge for the PR?

I understood your previous message as you having no problem with TelegramClient.jl design. If that's the case, I would really welcome any input (including PRs) to add missing functionality.
Looking at LibTDJSON.jl source (https://github.com/bhftbootcamp/LibTDJSON.jl/blob/master/src/LibTDJSON.jl), I see functions that just wrap ccalls â€“ it's very easy to add these to TelegramClient.jl if needed.
Note that TelegramClient.jl already has some low-level api functions, see eg https://github.com/JuliaAPlavin/TelegramClient.jl/blob/master/src/api_raw.jl.

Still, of course you can decide that LibTDJSON.jl needs to be a separate package. In that case it's common and recommended to at least add some mention and comparison with existing packages to the README â€“ in this case, TelegramClient.jl that has been available for years.

[noblock]

@aplavin, I think itâ€™s not a problem to add a mention. By the way, since it has been available for many years, it probably wasnâ€™t actively used â€” we only recently fixed the cross-platform issues in the _jll build

> By the way, since it has been available for many years, it probably wasnâ€™t actively used â€” we only recently fixed the cross-platform issues in the _jll build

I had TelegramClient.jl code running (until ~end of 2024), it worked totally fine.

This pull request has been inactive for 30 days and will be automatically closed 7 days from now. If this pull request should not be closed, please either (1) fix the AutoMerge issues and re-trigger Registrator, which will automatically update the pull request, or (2) post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. [noblock]
This pull request has been inactive for more than 30 days and has automatically been closed. Feel free to register your package or version again once you fix the AutoMerge issues. [noblock]
